But the mother found her sons at the Electran gate, in a meadow where the lotus blooms, fighting out their duel with spears, like lions in their lair, eager to wound each other,

a murderous libation of blood already cold, owed to Hades, poured out by Ares. Then, taking from the dead a sword of hammered bronze, she plunged it in her flesh, and in sorrow for her sons fell with her arms around them. So the god who fulfills these sorrows has brought them all together on this day,
father, for our house.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: Today is the beginning of many troubles to the house of Oedipus; may he live to be more fortunate!

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Cease now your lamentations; it is time we thought of

their burial. Hear what I have to say, Oedipus. Eteocles, your son, left me to rule this land, by giving it as a dowry to Haemon with his marriage to your daughter Antigone. Therefore I will no longer allow you to dwell in this land;

for Teiresias clearly said that the city would never prosper as long as you made your home here. So begone! And I say this not in insult, nor because I am your enemy, but from fear that some calamity will come upon the land, through those avenging fiends of yours.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: O destiny! From the beginning, how you have created me wretched and unhappy, if any mortal ever was; for before I had left my mother’s womb and seen the light, Apollo foretold to Laius that I, then unborn, should become my father’s murderer; alas for me!

So, as soon as I was born, the father who begot me tried to kill me, thinking me his enemy, for it was fated he should die at my hand; so he sent me unweaned to make a pitiful meal for beasts; I escaped from that— would that Cithaeron

had sunk into hell’s yawning abyss, because it did not destroy me, but . . . Fate made me a slave in the service of Polybus. And I, poor wretch, after slaying my own father came to my mother’s bed, to her sorrow,

and begot sons that were my brothers, whom I have destroyed, by bequeathing to them the legacy of curses I received from Laius. For I was not born so foolish, that I should have contrived these things against my own eyes and my children’s life, without some god.

Let that pass. What am I, poor wretch, to do? Who now will be my guide and tend the blind man’s step? The one who is dead? If she were alive, I know well that she would. My pair of noble sons? But they are gone from me. But am I still so young myself that I can find a livelihood?

Where? O Creon, why do you seek in this way to kill me utterly? For you will kill me, if you banish me from the land. Yet I will never twine my arms about your knees and seem a coward, for I would not betray my former nobility, no! not for all my ills.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: You have spoken well, in refusing to touch my knees, but I could not allow you to dwell in the land. Of these dead, bear one at once to the palace; but the other, who came with strangers to sack his native town, the dead Polyneices,

cast forth unburied beyond the borders of this land. To all the race of Cadmus shall this be proclaimed: Whoever is caught decking his corpse with wreaths or giving it burial, shall be requited with death. let him be unwept, unburied, a meal for birds.
As for you, Antigone, leave your mourning for these lifeless three and go indoors, to lead your maiden life until to-morrow, when Haemon waits to marry you.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: O father, in what cruel misery are we plunged!

For you I mourn more than for the dead; for in your woes you do not have something that is grievous and something not; but you were born wholly unfortunate, father. As for you, new-made king, I ask you, who do you insult my father with banishment?
Why do you make laws over a helpless corpse?

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: This was Eteocles’ purpose, not mine.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: It is senseless, and you are a fool to obey it!

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: How so? Isn’t it right to carry out his commands?

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: No; not if they are wrong and ill-advised.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: What? Isn’t it right for that other to be given to the dogs?

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: No, for the vengeance you are exacting is not a lawful one.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Yes, if he was his country’s enemy, when not born an enemy.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Well, he rendered up his destiny to fate.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Let him now pay the penalty in his burial too.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: What crime did he commit, in coming to claim his portion of the land?

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Be very sure of this, he shall have no burial.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: I will bury him, although the state forbids.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Do so, and you will be making your own grave by his.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: A noble end, for two so near and dear to lie side by side!

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Seize and take her inside.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Oh, no! For I will not let go of this corpse.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: These are the god’s decrees, my girl, not what seems good to you.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: And this has been decreed, not to insult the dead.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Be sure that no one will sprinkle over the corpse the moistened dust.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: O Creon, by my mother Jocasta, I implore you!

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Your labor is in vain; you will not gain your prayer.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Let me only bathe the dead body.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: That would be part of what is forbidden by the city.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: At least let me bandage the cruel wounds.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: No; you will never pay honor to this corpse.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: O my dearest! At least I will kiss your mouth.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Do not let this mourning bring disaster on your marriage.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Marriage! Do you think I will marry your son while I am alive?

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Indeed you must; how will you escape the match?

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Then that night will find in me another Danaid bride!

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Do you see how boldly she reproaches me?

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Let the steel know, the sword be my witness!

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Why are you so eager to be released from this marriage?

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: I mean to share my hapless father’s exile.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: A noble spirit yours but there is some folly in it.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: And I will share his death, I tell you further.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: Go, leave the land; you will not murder my son. Exit Creon.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Daughter, for this loyal spirit I thank you.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: How could I marry, while you went into exile alone, father?

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Stay here and be happy; I will bear my own load of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: And who will tend you in your blindness, father?

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Where fate appoints, there I will fall and lie down upon the ground.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Where is Oedipus, and that famous riddle?

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Lost! One day blessed me, one destroyed me.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: May I not also share your sorrows?

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: To wander with her blinded father would be shameful for his daughter.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Not so, father, but glory, if she is discreet.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Lead me near, so that I may touch your mother’s corpse.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: There, embrace the aged form so dear to you.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: O mother, o most wretched wife!

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Pitiably she lies, who suffered every evil at once.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Where are the corpses of Eteocles, and of Polyneices?

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Here they both lie, stretched out side by side.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Lay my blind hand upon their poor faces.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: There, touch the dead, your children.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: O dear fallen sons, sad offspring of a sad father!

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: O my brother Polyneices, name most dear to me!

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Now the oracle of Loxias is being fulfilled, my child.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: What oracle? Do you have further woes to tell?

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: That I should die in Athens after a life of wandering.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Where? What fenced town in Attica will take you in?

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Hallowed Colonus, home of the god of horses. Come then, attend on your blind father, since you are eager to share his exile.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Go to unhappy exile; stretch forth your dear hand, my old father, taking me to guide you, like a breeze that guides the ships.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: See, I am advancing; be my guide, my poor child.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: I am, I am! The saddest maiden of all in Thebes.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Where am I placing my aged step? Bring my staff, child.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: This way, this way, come to me, place your steps here, like a dream in your strength.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Oh, oh, driving the old man in most wretched flight from the country!
Oh, oh! the terrible sorrows I have endured!

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Why do you speak of enduring? Justice does not see the wicked, and does not requite follies.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: I am the one who came into high songs of victory,
because I guessed the baffling riddle of the girl, half-maiden.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: You are bringing up again the reproach of the Sphinx. Talk no more of past success. This misery was in store for you all the while,
to become an exile from your country and die anywhere.
Leaving to my girlhood friends sad tears, I go forth from my native land, to roam as no maiden should.
Ah! This dutiful resolve towards my father’s suffering will make me famous. Alas for the insults heaped on you and on my brother, whose dead body goes from the house unburied,
poor boy! I will bury him secretly, though I have to die for it, father.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Show yourself to your companions.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: My own laments suffice.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: Go pray at the altars.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: They have enough of my piteous tale.

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: At least go seek the Bromian god in his untrodden sanctuary among the Maenads’ hills.

sp.speaker: Antigone
sp.l: Bromius, for whom I once dressed in the Theban fawn-skin and
danced upon the hills in the holy choir of Semele—shall I now offer the gods homage that is not homage?

sp.speaker: Oedipus
sp.l: O citizens of a famous country, look at me; I am Oedipus, who solved the famous riddle, and was the greatest of men,

I, who alone controlled the murderous Sphinx’s power, am now myself driven from the land in dishonor and misery. But why do I make this moan and useless lamentation? As a mortal, I must bear the constraint that the gods decree.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Greatly revered Victory,
may you occupy my life and never cease to crown me!
